awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Experimental, Numerical, and Case Studies of Landslide Mobility
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant will advance the understanding of landslide mobility. Rapid flow-like landslides such as mud flows, debris flows, and rock avalanches are capable of mobilizing large volumes of soil and rock and impacting large areas, often far from their source because of their high mobility. Globally, rapid flow-like landslides cause billions of dollars in damage and thousands of deaths and injuries each year. As evidenced by the recent Oso Landslide (March 22, 2014) in Snohomish County, Washington, landslide mobility remains poorly understood. This award supports fundamental research to provide the knowledge needed for advancing the understanding of landslide mobility, and reliably predicting landslide runout. Results from this research will improve current landslide hazard assessment and ultimately help reduce future losses to society from these devastating geohazards. The international component of this project will foster international collaborations that contribute to the training of globally-engaged engineering students.

The objective of this research is to advance the understanding of the effects of solid-like behaviors of landslide mass and fluid-solid interaction on landslide mobility, which play important roles but have been overlooked in the past. To achieve this objective, integrated experimental, numerical and case studies that span laboratory and field scales will be conducted. Laboratory-scale flume tests will be conducted to investigate the impact forces generated by a sliding mass on a rigid obstruction. The slide mass will have varied porosity, mass, and release height and pattern. In the numerical investigation, a three dimensional smoothed particle hydrodynamics model will be developed, which will incorporate the latest advancements in contact algorithms, formulations of landslide mobility, two-phase debris flow models, and parallel computing. The developed numerical model will be calibrated and validated against the laboratory-scale flume tests conducted in this research, well-documented field-scale flume tests conducted by others, and case histories of long-runout landslides. The fully validated numerical model will then be utilized to gain insights into the effects of internal stress field, fluid-solid interaction, and evolution of porosity, stiffness, and bulk density of the sliding mass on landslide mobility.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant was to advance the understanding of landslide mobility. Rapid flow-like landslides such as mud flows, debris flows, and rock avalanches are capable of mobilizing large volumes of soil and rock and impacting large areas, often far from their source because of their high mobility. To achieve this goal, integrated experimental, numerical and case studies that span laboratory and field scales were conducted. Laboratory-scale flume tests were conducted to investigate the flow front velocity, final deposit profile, and the impact force generated by a granular sliding mass on a rigid obstruction for different combinations of inclination angle and basal friction angle, focusing on the transition between fluid-like and solid-like behaviors of the sliding mass (see Figure 1). A semi-analytical equation was developed to link the impact force and granular flow parameters. In the numerical investigation, a 3D smoothed particle hydrodynamics model was developed, which incorporated the latest advancements in contact algorithms, formulations of landslide mobility, and parallel computing. The developed model was used to simulate quasi-static collapse of granular columns (3D) and the laboratory flume tests (2D) to gain insights into the effects of granular soil behaviors on the deposit profile, runout, and impact forces (see Figure 2). Through international collaborations, landslide case histories at the field scale were developed.

 

This project has provided direct support to the research and training activities of three Ph.D. students and two undergraduate students to the completion of their respective degrees. A course module was developed for first-year engineering students to gain hands-on lab experience with soil flume tests. It was found that students were more interested in participating in research or learning more about research activities after the hands-on experience. For outreach activities, the project team participated in the State College School District-wide ?Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day?, where the project team demonstrated soil flume tests to elementary school kids. For outreach to a broader audience, the PI worked on a book on landslides as a content consultant, which was written for students in 4th ? 6th grade.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2021
Modified by: Tong Qiu

    Amir Ahmadipur, Tong Qiu, and Bahman Sheikh

  • Figure 2. Isometric view of velocity contour of a granular column at different time (s): (a) rough basal surface; (b) smooth basal surface.
    Bahman Sheikh, Tong Qiu, and Amir Ahmadipur
    Copyrighted
